pullRequest.body:
The "assertNotExists" style linter checks that a file starts with
```lean
import*
doc-module*
assert_not_exists*
[no more assert_not_exists]
```
It emits a warning on each `assert_not_exists` that is not preceded by
* possibly some `import` statements,
* possibly some doc-module strings, and
* possibly some `assert_not_exists` commands
in this order.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [13d7c77972](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15724/commits/13d7c779723975ef55b785e4f47e3e3efa8b6c45)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Tactic.Linter | 14 | 16 | +2 (+14.29%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
There are 4062 files with changed transitive imports: this is too many to display!

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ assertNotExistsLinter`
`+ getLinterAssertNotExists`
`+ onlyImportsModDocsAsserts`
`+ parseUpToHere`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

Quick comment for now; if I can, I will return to this later this week.
First of all, thanks for writing this linter. (Follow-up question: can you write a similar linter to check if a module docstring is present? Then, we could retire the corresponding *Python* style linter. I'll happily review such a PR.)
Can you rename the linter to something more descriptive? From the name, I thought *this* linter would check that all declarations referenced in `assert_not_exist` eventually exist, but this one is not it.

Eric, your comment made me think that maybe the implementation of `assert_not_exists` could include a persistent change to the environment that an associated linter could then pick up.  Looking at the lean3 code that you mentioned seems like what the lean3 linter was doing as well.

I'll see if I can implement it like this, thanks!

Michael, let me try to implement the doc-module *style* linter.  It should be relatively straightforward to make it so that it flags an improperly formatted file when it reaches the `eoi` syntax.  This means that all the file would have to be processed before you get a warning.  Otherwise, it is a little tricky to make sure that it only process the "preamble" once.
Oh, I forgot to mention: I inserted `Style` after `Linter` in the namespace: hopefully this makes the intent of this linter clearer.

> Oh, I forgot to mention: I inserted `Style` after `Linter` in the namespace: hopefully this makes the intent of this linter clearer.

You could (additionally) refer to this as the "`assert_not_exists` style" linter, perhaps that would make it *even* clearer. (The style namespace already helps!)

> Eric, your comment made me think that maybe the implementation of `assert_not_exists` could include a persistent change to the environment that an associated linter could then pick up. Looking at the lean3 code that you mentioned seems like what the lean3 linter was doing as well.
> 
> I'll see if I can implement it like this, thanks!

That would be great, and sounds like the best way forward!
To record what happened on zulip: it seems sensible to require `assert_not_imported` to come right before `assert_not_exists` commands.

In lean3 we had an `assertNotExists` linter that detected whether the definitions actually exist elsewhere in mathlib. Can we name this one something else, to disambiguate? Perhaps `linters.style.assertNotExists` etc?
What does `Hash` stand for here?

I copied the name from the first linter that I wrote, probably using code that Mario wrote, created a template for linters and never went back to think about it again.

I do not know what it stands for... :shrug:
I suspect this is left from the hash command linter?
It could be!  Time for a big replacement `Hash` --> `LinterName`!  :smile:

pullRequest.title: test: the `assertNotExists` style linter

Quick comment for now; if I can, I will return to this later this week.
First of all, thanks for writing this linter. (Follow-up question: can you write a similar linter to check if a module docstring is present? Then, we could retire the corresponding *Python* style linter. I'll happily review such a PR.)
Can you rename the linter to something more descriptive? From the name, I thought *this* linter would check that all declarations referenced in `assert_not_exist` eventually exist, but this one is not it.

In lean3 we had an `assertNotExists` linter that detected whether the definitions actually exist elsewhere in mathlib. Can we name this one something else, to disambiguate? Perhaps `linters.style.assertNotExists` etc?

Eric, your comment made me think that maybe the implementation of `assert_not_exists` could include a persistent change to the environment that an associated linter could then pick up.  Looking at the lean3 code that you mentioned seems like what the lean3 linter was doing as well.

I'll see if I can implement it like this, thanks!

Michael, let me try to implement the doc-module *style* linter.  It should be relatively straightforward to make it so that it flags an improperly formatted file when it reaches the `eoi` syntax.  This means that all the file would have to be processed before you get a warning.  Otherwise, it is a little tricky to make sure that it only process the "preamble" once.
Oh, I forgot to mention: I inserted `Style` after `Linter` in the namespace: hopefully this makes the intent of this linter clearer.

> Oh, I forgot to mention: I inserted `Style` after `Linter` in the namespace: hopefully this makes the intent of this linter clearer.

You could (additionally) refer to this as the "`assert_not_exists` style" linter, perhaps that would make it *even* clearer. (The style namespace already helps!)

> Eric, your comment made me think that maybe the implementation of `assert_not_exists` could include a persistent change to the environment that an associated linter could then pick up. Looking at the lean3 code that you mentioned seems like what the lean3 linter was doing as well.
> 
> I'll see if I can implement it like this, thanks!

That would be great, and sounds like the best way forward!
To record what happened on zulip: it seems sensible to require `assert_not_imported` to come right before `assert_not_exists` commands.
